Furthermore, the Home Office have taken the line that negotiations for the conclusion of an extradition treaty with a foreign country should not, for the future, be entered upon unless the foreign country concerned has adopted the Standard Minimum Rules for the Treatment of Prisoners which have been recommended by the International Prison Commission. 5. In these circumstances it would, in our opinion, be undesirable to embark upon negotiations with Muscat for the conclusion of an extradition treaty under the United Kingdom Extradition Acts. G. We observe that the Indian Extradition Act, 1903, contains provisions regarding the surrender of fugitive criminals in the case of States other than Foreign States. The expression 'Foreign State' is defined in the Act as meaning a State to which, for the time being, the Extradition Acts, 1870 and 1873, apply. It might perhaps be suggested to the Government of India that they should consider the possibility of concluding a treaty with Muscat under this Act. There is much to be said for refusing in this particular case, to accept a binding obligation to surrender a national of any third State; and/and we think the obligation should he limited to persons who are Muscat subjects or who are nationals of Koweit, Bahrein, Qatar, the Trucial States or (if the Colonial Office agree) of the Aden Protectorate, and (again, if the Colonial Office agree) nationals of Zanzibar of Omani origin who own property in Muscat (see the definition of ’’British Protected Persons” in Article 4 of the Muscat Order-in-Council 1939). As regards the form of such a treaty, there would appear to be no objection to its being concluded between His Majesty and the Sultan. We agree that the initial drafting might well be left to the local authorities. 7 . The question of making arrangements with the Sultan for the arrest and handing over to His Majesty’s Consul of British subjects who are fugitives from justice is one on which we find it difficult to offer any suggestion. Article 13 (3) of the Treaty of the 5th February, 1939, provides in effect that no British subject shall be arrested etc. by an officer of the Sultan save under an order signed by His Majesty’s Consul and that any British subject arrested etc. shall be placed in the custody of His Majesty’s Consul. It may be that the presentationof a signed order to the Muscat authorities would be sufficient to achieve the arrest of a wanted British subject; but perhaps your Department may be able to suggest some other method. October,1939. 2. The first point on which we should be glad to have the views of the Foreign Office relates to the scope of the treaty. Theoretically, perhaps, it should be treated as a corollary to the recent Treaty of Friendship, Commerce and Navigation and so, on our side, be made for the United Kingdom and India, with provision for the accession of the Dominions and for extension to the Colonies. Although it is true, as stated by the Sultan, that there is ''no connection 1 ' between him and the Government of India 'to bind either party' in the matter of extradition of offenders, I doubt whether it is correct to say - as the Political Aaviser observes - that 'the 'e is no machinery that can be set in motion to obtain the surrender of a Muscat subject who has fled' (presumably into British India). There is in fact such machinery in Part III of the Indian Extradition Act, and the existence of a specific treaty is not, as far as I can see, a condition precedent to the setting in motion of that machinery, - although, of course, in the absence of any treaty, the Government of India would have an unfettered discretion to refuse to hand over a fugitive, whether application for his surrender was made under s.7 or under s.9 of the Act. As for the converse case, viz. - the surrender by # the Sultan of fugitive criminals, I note that the Political Adv-ireer confines his comment (and suggestion) to the case of fugitive British subjects. He agrees that in theory there is in their case no necessity for any agreement as to extradition, but adds that such an agreement would facilitate their apprehension in practice. But, however that may be, there is, I assume, no way at by rUc present open to secure the surrender of such fugitives fporc justice in British India as are not British subjects. Z. The Government of India have no objection to an extradition treaty being concluded with His Highness the Sultan of Muscat on the lines proposed. If the treaty is to be confined to extradition between British India and Muscat, it will presumably not be between the United Kingdom and Muscat, but between His Majesty acting in respect of his Indian Possessions and His Highness the Sultan of Muscat. mods.abstract: Correspondence, draft papers, and minute papers relating to a proposal for an extradition treaty between the Sultan of Muscat and Oman and the Government of India. The idea is first suggested by the Sultan himself, Said bin Taimur [Sa‘īd ibn Taymūr Āl Bū Sa‘īd], and is then discussed in exchanges between officials at the Political Agency in Muscat, Political Residency in the Persian Gulf, Government of India (External Affairs Department), India Office, and Foreign Office.
